author: STAFF REPORT
title: PIAA expanding to 6 classes for football
text:
PIAA expanding to 6 classes for football STAFF REPORT JASON FARMER / STAFF PHOTOGRAPHER A pair of Abington Heights defenders close in on Wallenpaupack’s Tyler Hertzog during Sunday’s Lackawanna Football Conference Division I game. Abington Heights won, 10-7. 
The high school football landscape in Pennsylvania has changed. 
The PIAA Board of Directors approved an expansion from four to six classifications this afternoon beginning with the 2016 season. It’s the biggest change the sport has seen since the state playoffs were adopted for the 1988 season. 
The new system takes effect starting with the 2016 season and divides schools into classes of roughly equal size. 
In addition, the PIAA also approved to expand from four to six classes in boys and girls basketball, softball and baseball. Boys and girls soccer and girls volleyball will expand to four classes, while field hockey is expanding to three classes. Lacrosse is expanding to two classes. 
The football expansion was approved by a 26-4 vote. The other sports were approved, 23-7. 
Today’s vote is the culmination of a long process that began with three proposals. Other options included six classifications with a Super Class for schools with an enrollment of 700 or more, and a Super Class with schools with enrollment of 800 or more. 
As the months passed, options were eliminated through the review process that included meetings of the Strategic Planning and Football Steering committees and the Pennsylvania Scholastic Football Coaches Association, which had strong support for change. 
Last month, the Strategic Planning and Football Steering Committee recommended a to move to six classifications with an even break of roughly 96 football teams per classification. 
Check back for updates, or read more in The Times-Tribune on Thursday.
